Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Better Use of Science: A Study of Boundary Spanning Environmental Processes in Georgia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates how to better bridge science and environmental policy by investigating boundary spanning processes, through which scientific information can be incorporated into policymaking. These processes are mainly conducted through organizations which bring together scientists and policymakers in a range of ways to enhance the integration of science and policy. This research systematically investigates the processes of boundary organizations and factors which may enable or constrain successful incorporation of science into environmental policy and will provide an understanding of how to effectively bridge science and policy. In a world where persistent environmental problems exist, this work will ultimately provide the necessary tools for a better understanding of the complexities associated with integrating science into environmental policy.

This project provides an in-depth look into the factors which support boundary organizations in incorporating science into environmental policy. During this in-depth research, ineffective boundary spanning processes will also likely be found. Therefore, to uncover both the factors which support and limit the incorporation of science into environmental policy, this study will closely examine three water policy case studies in the state of Georgia: (1) the 2008 Georgia Comprehensive Statewide Water Policy, (2) the 2012 Georgia Moratorium on Groundwater Withdrawals, and (3) policy debates related to stream buffers or riparian zones. Each of these case studies involved the participation of scientists, boundary organizations, and policymakers during creation and implementation of water policy. Individual and group interviews will be conducted to analyze whether and how science was integrated into each water policy and what boundary spanning processes affected the outcome. An analysis of media accounts and secondary documents will more fully explain the factors which may have influenced whether and how science was integrated in each case study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Overview: How can environmental science better serve society? In what ways is environmental science currently offered to decision makers, and how does this impact policy decisions? What informal factors influence the extent to and ways in which science is used to shape policy decision processes? This dissertation research contributed to the scholarship of science-policy linkages through a meta-synthesis of published case studies on boundary spanning processes and a multi-sited ethnographic analysis of three water policy case studies in the state of Georgia. National Science Foundation funding supported lodging, travel, and the cost of essential materials and supplies for the ethnographic component of this project. 

Intellectual Merit: The proposed research advanced theory building on boundary organizations while testing core assumptions and identifying limitations of boundary organization theory. It also expanded our understanding of what informal factors and processes, including the presence of informal hierarchies and other properties emergent from informal social interactions, shape the science-policy interface. Fundamentally, this research provided additional information on which mechanisms enhance the incorporation of science into environmental policy. 

Broader Impacts: This project was significant for its ability to inform efforts to strengthen the science-policy interface, both in the state of Georgia and more broadly. In examining the role of science within the wider hierarchy of influences on decision-making, and the role of formal and informal factors in shaping outcomes, actors engaged in environmental issues in Georgia (the legislature, citizen groups, scientists) and nation-wide are better equipped to address environmental concerns in the future. In addition, this research contributed to our understanding of the conditions under which science can play a meaningful role in the successful implementation of sound environmental policy. Explicating fine-tuned details of boundary spanning processes within wider political and institutional contexts and interpersonal interactions through in-depth ethnographic inquiry illuminated constraints, best practices, and areas for future research in how science can best serve society.
